title: About eBirdCBC
text: eBirdCBC is a collaborative project that leverages eBird data and advanced algorithms to enhance the compilation of area lists for Christmas Bird Counts (CBCs). The project combines the expertise of Durrell Kapan and Mark Schulist, with the support of many dedicated individuals conducting eBird-powered CBCs. Examples include the Abbotts Lagoon subarea (#23) of the Point Reyes CBC and the Tennessee Valley subarea of the Southern Marin CBC.

title: About eBirdCBC
text:
Background
The Christmas Bird Count (CBC) is a long-standing community science project that has been instrumental in bird conservation efforts. To encourage greater participation, it’s beneficial to bridge the traditional, primarily analog methods of the CBC with modern, digitally enabled practices like eBirding. This integration can make the CBC more accessible and engaging, attracting a broader audience and enhancing data collection.
For more information on the CBC and to find a count near you, visit the Audubon Christmas Bird Count page. To explore eBirding and how it complements the CBC, check out eBird’s official website.Purpose

title: About eBirdCBC
text:
Mission
The primary mission of eBirdCBC is to:

Encourage more people to join Christmas Bird Counts (CBCs) by bridging the gap between eBirders, immersed in digitally enabled birding, and the Christmas Bird Count community, who primarily use analog methods in this long-standing community science project.
Providing tools to efficiently integrate multiple eBird checklists into the CBC area and count-circle compilation workflows.
Make it easy to employ the “Max-Sum”™ algorithm to differentiate overlapping and independent checklists for accurate species lists.
Document existing CBC community and count-circle count-area knowledge on a persistent platform (eBird).
Foster collaboration and innovation in bird monitoring efforts.

title: About eBirdCBC
text:
Meet the Team

Dr. Durrell D. Kapan: Senior Research Fellow, California Academy of Sciences. Concept, analog ‘model iterations’, MAX-SUM algorithm, protocol iteration as area leader on two CBC counts.
Mark Schulist: eBirdCBC primary developer, programming, website design, and protocol iteration with extensive participation in CBC activities.
This project also relies on the efforts of countless volunteers on CBCs who put up with being test subjects as well as all bird enthusiasts who contribute to the success of CBCs across the region.

We extend our gratitude to the birding community for their dedication and contributions to the CBC tradition. Your participation in CBCs helps continue the 123-year legacy (since 1900) of advancing a deeper understanding of bird populations and their conservation.

title: eBirdCBC Protocol
section: Preparing for an eBird-Powered Count Area
text:
Preparing for an eBird-Powered Count Area

Work together to divide the count subareas into non-overlapping routes.
Map these routes and define clear boundaries forming distinct polygons.
Color-code the polygons to reduce confusion.
Build team assignments based on these color-coded polygons.

title: eBirdCBC Protocol
text:
In-Field Methods

Each team covers their assigned route/polygon starting early in the day.
Create a new eBird list for each unique count area (polygon) with eBird tracks enabled. This forms the basis for both bird observations and CBC effort data (see below for hints on manual data collection).
For large polygons, create multiple lists.
Track total party miles and total party hours.
Transcribe eBird data and manual effort notes into eBird list comments.
When crossing into other teams’ polygons, create separate lists to collect replicate eBird data. These data will be compared and we will use the \*high counts\* (e.g. =MAX) for overlapping stationary birds.
Do not include birds seen by people outside your CBC party.
Start new lists frequently for outlined subareas within your polygon.
Record birds seen between polygons in the species comments with relevant details.

title: eBirdCBC Protocol
section: Manual methods (effort, raptors, or all birds)
text:
Manual methods (effort, raptors, or all birds)

Assign a team member to log effort, raptors, and rare bird notes on paper for transcription into the appropriate eBird field (like time/distance) and/or the eBird memo.
Include the following in effort notes:

Team name, participant name and number (who is there matters), list numbers, start/stop times and locations, weather, and raptor/rare bird sightings.
Track total party miles (one-way distance) and total party hours (nearest minute).
Document raptors and rare birds according to the provided guidelines (see below).
Ensure your effort notes match each separate list (e.g. separate area/polygon).
Note, if you have started you eBird track for a polygon/site if you prefer (or are running low on battery) you can do the rest on paper and merge it later (see suggested data format):

Log date, location (site name), and other details
Log effort
Log all birds
Log rare birds

title: eBirdCBC Protocol
text:
Raptors and Large Flying Birds
Raptors and large flying birds are crucial to track for accurate counts and movement patterns:

Record species, age, sex, plumage, time, location, flight direction, behavior, and other details.
Use a paper tally sheet to ensure data consistency.
Add this information to species comments in eBird after the count.
These data help prevent double-counting across subareas and are required for compilation.

title: eBirdCBC Protocol
section: Why Use eBird for Christmas Bird Counts?
text:
Why Use eBird for Christmas Bird Counts?
Integrating eBird into CBCs simplifies data compilation, captures local knowledge, and improves accuracy. By combining eBird lists and the MAX-SUM™ algorithm, we:

Eliminate double-counting and confusion.
Enhance repeatability and data reliability.
Preserve cultural and local knowledge about count areas and team deployment.

This hybrid approach ensures the long-term success of the CBC as the world’s longest-running community science project while adapting to the information age.
